title: ‘Sometimes You Have to Lie’: Louise Fitzhugh’s Rebellion
sub_head: The creator of ‘Harriet the Spy’ was a literary outsider herself.
body: From an acorn comes the oak. From a few typewritten pages without illustration came 11-year-old Harriet M. Welsch, one of the great 20th-century heroines of children’s fiction. Harriet’s creator, Louise Fitzhugh, had not wholly thought through her idea for a story about “a nasty little girl who keeps a notebook on all her friends.” It was 1963, and Fitzhugh (1928-74), an artist and writer, was casting about for a new way to make money; pitching the synopsis of a children’s book seemed like a good idea.
